Abstract: The resurrection of the 1918 influenza virus, facilitated by reverse genetics, has provided profound insights into the mechanisms of virulence and transmission that characterized one of the deadliest pandemics in history. By reconstructing the virus, researchers have been able to identify specific genetic markers responsible for its high pathogenicity and rapid spread. Studies have revealed that the hemagglutinin and polymerase genes played crucial roles in the virus's ability to infect and replicate efficiently in human hosts. Additionally, the research has underscored the importance of host immune response in determining disease severity. These findings have not only enhanced our understanding of the 1918 pandemic but have also informed current strategies for pandemic preparedness and vaccine development. The work highlights the potential risks and ethical considerations of manipulating highly pathogenic viruses, emphasizing the need for stringent biosafety measures in such research endeavors.
